author: democratandchronicle.com
title: State providing foam to fight oil fires
text:
ALBANY â€“ New York is deploying 19 trailers equipped with a firefighting foam to local fire departments and county departments to help them fight fires or contain crude oil spills. New York has faced growing concerns about the potential of explosions and spills if trains hauling volatile crude oil were to derail. In May, the state Department of Environmental Conservation said it would develop individual geographic response plans for 20 counties that have the highest risks for a derailment.
The state Division of Homeland Security and Emergency Services said the foam trailers will be located in population centers along major rail lines and waterways, including in Buffalo, Kingston and Newburgh.
They will also be provided to fire departments in Binghamton, Elmira, Oneonta, Rochester and to Rockland County. They should be operational by early next year.
"This new equipment will help ensure first responders in these communities are prepared in the event of an emergency involving crude oil, or other highly flammable substances," Gov. Andrew Cuomo said in a statement. "Today's action is the latest in a multi-pronged effort to prepare state and local authorities in the event of a crude oil disaster."
Each trailer has a foam concentrate that can be applied to roadways and oil by adding water.
